questiontext.text:
Example Eksempel

Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the \(3\times 3\) matrix Finn egenverdiene og egenvektorene til \(3\times 3\) matrisen

\[A=\begin{bmatrix} 2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{bmatrix}\]

Solution Løsning

The eigenvalues and eigenvectors are found by solving the eigenvalue problem Egenverdiene og egenvektorene bestemmes ved å løse egenverdiproblemet.

\[A\underline{x}=\lambda \underline{x} \qquad \underline{x}=\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y\\ z\end{bmatrix}\]

Proceeding as in the previous example: Vi fortsetter som i det forrige eksempelet:

\((A-\lambda I)\underline{x}=\underline{0}\) and non-trivial solutions for \(\underline{x}\) will exist if \(\det(A-\lambda I)=0.\) \((A-\lambda I)\underline{x}=\underline{0}\) og ikke-trivielle løsninger for \(\underline{x}\) vil eksistere hvis \(\det(A-\lambda I)=0.\)

That is, Det vil si,

\[\det\left\{\begin{bmatrix} 2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{bmatrix} -\lambda\begin{bmatrix} 1&0&0\\ 0&1&0\\ 0&0&1\end{bmatrix}\right\}=0\]

i.e., dvs.,

\[\begin{vmatrix} 2-\lambda&-1&0\\ -1&2-\lambda&-1\\ 0&-1&2-\lambda\end{vmatrix}=0\]

Expanding this determinant we find: Utvidelse av denne determinanten gir oss:

\[(2-\lambda)\begin{vmatrix} 2-\lambda&-1\\ -1&2-\lambda\end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} -1&-1\\ 0&2-\lambda\end{vmatrix} = 0\]

that is, det vil si,

\[(2-\lambda)\left\{(2-\lambda)^2-1\right\}-(2-\lambda)=0\]

Taking out the common factor \((2-\lambda)\): Vi tar ut fellesfaktoren \((2-\lambda)\):

\[(2-\lambda)\left\{4-4\lambda+\lambda^2-1-1\right\}\]

which gives: som gir:

\[(2-\lambda)\left[\lambda^2-4\lambda+2\right]=0.\]

This is easily solved to give \(\lambda =2\) or \(\lambda = \dfrac{4\pm \sqrt{16-8}}{2} = 2\pm \sqrt{2}\). Dette løses enkelt og gir \(\lambda = 2\) eller \(\lambda = \dfrac{4\pm \sqrt{16-8}}{2} = 2\pm \sqrt{2}\).

So (typically) we have found three possible values of \(\lambda\) for this \(3\times 3\) matrix \(A\). Så (typisk) har vi funnet tre mulige verdier av \(\lambda\) for denne \(3\times 3\) matrisen \(A\).

To each value of \(\lambda\) there corresponds an eigenvector. Til hver verdi av \(\lambda\) er det en egenvektor.

Case 1: \(\lambda = 2 - \sqrt{2}\) (lowest eigenvalue) Tilfelle 1: \(\lambda = 2 - \sqrt{2}\) (laveste egenverdi)

Then \(A\underline{x}=(2-\sqrt{2})\underline{x}\) implies Da impliserer \(A\underline{x}=(2-\sqrt{2})\underline{x}\) at

\[\left\{\begin{alignedat}{3} 2x & {}-{} & y & & & = (2 - \sqrt{2})x \\ -x & {}+{} & 2y & {}-{} & z & = (2 - \sqrt{2})y \\ & & -y & {}+{} & 2z & = (2 - \sqrt{2})z \end{alignedat}\right.\]

Simplifying, Vi forenkler,

\begin{alignat}{3} \sqrt{2}x & {}-{} & y & & & = 0 \tag{a} \\ -x & {}+{} & \sqrt{2}y & {}-{} & z & = 0 \tag{b} \\ & & -y & {}+{} & \sqrt{2}z &= 0 \tag{c} \end{alignat}

We conclude the following: Vi konkluderer med følgende:

\[\text{(c)} \implies y = \sqrt{2}z \qquad \text{(a)} \implies y = \sqrt{2}x\]

These two relations give \(x=z\), then \(\text{(b)} \implies -x+2x-x=0\). Disse to relasjonene gir \(x=z\), så \(\text{(b)} \implies -x+2x-x=0\).

The last equation gives us no information; it simply states that \(0=0\). Den siste ligningen gir oss ingen informasjon; den sier rett og slett at \(0=0\).

Therefore, \(\underline{x}=\begin{bmatrix} x\\ \sqrt{2}x\\ x\end{bmatrix}) for any \(x\neq 0\) (otherwise we would have the trivial solution). So the eigenvectors corresponding to eigenvalue \(\lambda =2-\sqrt{2}\) are all proportional to \(\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ \sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{bmatrix}\). Derfor er \(\underline{x}=\begin{bmatrix} x\\ \sqrt{2}x\\ x\end{bmatrix}\) for alle \(x\neq 0\) (ellers ville vi hatt den trivielle løsningen). Så egenvektorene som tilsvarer egenverdien \(\lambda =2-\sqrt{2}\) er alle proporsjonale med \(\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ \sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{bmatrix}\).

In normalised form we have an eigenvector \(\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right].\) I normalisert form har vi en egenvektor \(\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right].\)

Case 2: \(\lambda = 2\) Tilfelle 2: \(\lambda = 2\)

Here \(A\underline{x}=2\underline{x}\) implies Her impliserer \(A\underline{x}=2\underline{x}\)

\[\left[\begin{array}{rrr}2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right]=2\left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right]\]

i.e., dvs.,

\[\left\{\begin{alignedat}{3} 2x & {}-{} & y & & & = 2x \\ -x & {}+{} & 2y & {}-{} & z & = 2y \\ & & -y & {}+{} & 2z & = 2z \end{alignedat}\right.\]

After simplifying the equations become: Etter å ha forenklet ligningene, blir de:

\begin{alignat}{3} & & -y & & &= 0 \tag{a} \\ -x & & & {}-{} & z &= 0 \tag{b} \\ & & -y & & & = 0 \tag{c} \end{alignat}

\(\text{(a)}\) and \(\text{(c)}\) imply \(y=0\), while \(\text{(b)}\) implies \(x=-z\). \(\text{(a)}\) og \(\text{(c)}\) impliserer \(y=0\), mens \(\text{(b)}\) impliserer \(x=-z\).

Therefore, the eigenvectors have the form \(\left[\begin{array}{r}x\\0\\-x\end{array}\right]\) for any \(x\ne 0\). Derfor har egenvektorene formen \(\left[\begin{array}{r}x\\0\\-x\end{array}\right]\) for enhver \(x\ne 0\).

That is, eigenvectors corresponding to \(\lambda=2\) are all proportional to \(\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\-1\end{array}\right]\). Det vil si, egenvektor for \(\lambda=2\) er proporsjonal med \(\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\-1\end{array}\right]\).

In normalised form we have an eigenvector \(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\-1\end{array}\right]\). I normalisert form har vi en egenvektor \(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\-1\end{array}\right]\).

Case 3: \(\lambda = 2 + \sqrt{2}\) (largest eigenvalue) Tilfelle 3: \(\lambda = 2 + \sqrt{2}\) (største egenverdi)

Proceeding along similar lines to cases 1 and 2 above we find that the eigenvectors corresponding to \(\lambda=2+\sqrt{2}\) are each proportional to \(\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\-\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\) with normalised eigenvector \(\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ -\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\). Fortsetter vi på lignende måte som i case 1 og 2 over, finner vi at egenvektorene som tilsvarer \(\lambda=2+\sqrt{2}\) er proporsjonale med \(\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\-\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\) med normalisert egenvektor \(\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ -\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\).

In conclusion, the matrix \(A %=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ %0&-1&2\end{array}\right]\) has three distinct eigenvalues: Konklusjonen er at matrisen \(A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{array}\right]\) har tre distinkte egenvaerdiene:

\[\lambda_1=2-\sqrt{2},\qquad \lambda_2=2\qquad \lambda_3=2+\sqrt{2}\]

and three corresponding normalised eigenvectors: og tre tilsvarer normaliserte egenvektorer:

\[\underline{x}_1=\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ \sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right],\qquad \underline{x}_2=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\ 0\\-1\end{array}\right],\qquad \underline{x}_3=\dfrac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\-\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\]

Note that even when normalised we have a choice of vector, namely \(\underline{v}\) and \(-\underline{v}\). Merk at selv når normalisert kan vi velge vektor, nemlig \(\underline{v}\) og \(-\underline{v}\).
